intro: Arthraxon hispidus subsp. centrasiaticus, commonly known as the Central Asian rough grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the grass family Poaceae and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as steppes and rocky soils. Its leaves are narrow and linear, with a rough texture due to the presence of stiff hairs. The inflorescence consists of a compact cluster of spikelets, which produce small, wind-pollinated flowers.
